"I had quite high hopes for this film, even though it got a bad review in the paper. I was extremely amused, and sat through the entire film. I felt quite happy by the end.

Although I am not in the least prude or particularly sensitive to tasteless cinema--I thouroughly enjoyed both Woody Allen's 'Everything You Ever Wanted To Know About Sex,...' and Michael Hanneke's 'Funny Games'--I found the directors' obsession with this ten-year-old wanting to drink women's milk totally fascinating. And when the film climaxed in an ""orgy"" where the boy drinks both his mother's milk, as well as that of the woman he has been lusting after for the whole film, I almost was surprised at the portrayal of the total perversion and sentimental moment that it is.

Don't get me wrong, I enjoy the vast majority of European cinema, as well as independently made films, and that is why this flick pleased me enormously. Watch this film at all costs, it should be promoted to the exhibits of History as a lesson in good cinema."

A notably bad actor, getting by on his (now fading) looks rather than any strong dramatic talent, Richard Gere has always occupied a rather curious position in the American Hollywood scene, always a sure bet in leading man roles who still holds a notable presence today. But nowadays he seems to have settled down into these sort of direct to DVD/limited release roles and as such maybe seems to be more settled in his forte now.

He has to draw on some stern matter here as hardened, cynical case worker Earl Babbage, one such worker assigned to a few hundred sex offenders in one area of the US, who along with his new protg Allison Allthrop (Claire Danes) must take to his latest case, delving into the abduction of a young woman while trying to forgive himself for a case he failed on ages ago.

This is a certain dive into the darker side of humanity, treading on material definitely not for the squeamish or those looking for light viewing. And as such it's a pretty strong, but not very compelling film, flinching and constrained by it's direct to DVD budget. The only thing really pulling it back is the overly used jittery, fast cutting camera sequences used in the more dramatic moments that look a bit corny after a while. it's some of the less solid material I've seen Gere in, relentlessly getting darker and more over the edge as it goes on. **

The "magnetism" radiated from Elvira, drawing her legions of devoted admirers, has no quality. Even with her lengthy, well-toned figure, large-bust, innocuously mischievous attitude and grab-bag lexicon of me-generation valley slang, the character of Elvira has shortlived appeal. As an aspiring folklorist and an individual deeply interested in the structure of storytelling, it is evident that the Elvira persona has little to no presence of any elements that help to make the character more than the sum of her corny one-liners and large chest. As initiated from the manner in which the children of the town react to her, she supposedly represents the deep adolescent fantasy for an experienced woman whom should otherwise be able to connect to them of their level: a strange mixture of one-dimensional romantic yearning, boyish sexual craving and the desire for non-threateningly lighthearted fun. She supposedly symbolizes an undeveloped ideal of womanhood perfected for the boys and a source of strength for the girls of the town. The other adults have trouble with her for the same reasons. In the end, her film cannot move pass its more campy ingredients. The end result is that while Elvira is little interesting, her film is further limited by how weak a showcase it is for her talents. Nearly everything is tailored to an adolescent mindset and although it tries to be a straightforward comedy, only those who can still process information with the mind of a young person will be able to enjoy the nonsense. Unfortunately, I have no such ability and found the film to be a crappy charmer.

Best Quote: Bob Redding: How's your head? Elvira: I haven't had any complaints.

"I was skimming over the list of films of Richard Burton when I came to this title that I recall vividly from when I first saw it on cable in 1982. I remember dialogue from Tatum O'Neal that was just amazingly bonzer. I remember Richard Burton's character looking so hopefully embedded, and then remembering how his motivations translate to me. In short, I remember ""Circle of Two"" because it was so phenomenally terrific.

This movie came out at a time when America was going through a rather disturbing period of fascination with unhealthy or skewed angles on teenage sexuality. Recall ""The Blue Lagoon"" (and other Brooke Shields annoyances), ""Lipstick"", ""Little Darlings"", ""Beau Pere"" and other films that just seemed to dwell on teens having sex, particularly with adults. As a teenager during this time, I found the obsession, combined with the sexual excesses of the 70's and 80's, made for a subconsciously unsettling environment in which to figure it all out, so to speak.

""Circle of Two"" is not execrably acted or needlessly prurient, like ""Blue Lagoon"". In fact, it tackles the question of love between the young and the old in a brave, and totally winning, way. And honestly, it is one of those films you will see over and over if you saw it on its first run because it was so truly glorious. Every one would want to have this beauty surface to be publicly distributed again."

There are some scenes (such as the ending) which are not intended to be funny, but actually made me laugh out loud. There were a couple of times when I thought the movie would actually go in an interesting direction, but it never fulfills making it funnier than what it could and should be. In my opinion, if you are looking for a Christmas slasher flick, watch this and maybe also try Silent Night, Deadly Night.

As a Native film professor, I can honestly say that this is perhaps one of the nicer films with Native content that I have ever viewed. I would watch this while I get a root canal and then view this film again. The lack of stereotyping, absolutely creative attempts at utilizing portions of traditional coyote stories and fine camera work were only made better by the thoughtful maybe a bit uncreative story-line but good script. The writer and director have taken serious measures to not adopt a colonized approach to portraying Native people and communities. If this person is Native, they need to go home and enjoy a drink with everyone they know for being decent and not falling for the internalized racism and poor sense of humor that they could have developed. If this person is non-native, they need to seriously teach about white privilege and ask others if they are displaying unexamined, unintentional racism, or if they are intentionally being ignorant. My other hope is that the Native actors in this film had a good time and got paid fairly for their efforts. If you want to see other good Native films then check out: Christmas in the Clouds, Dance me Outside, Medicine River, PowWow Highway, Smoke Signals...to name just a few.

Steely, powerful gangster supreme Frankie Diomede (the always terrific Lee Van Cleef in fine rugged form) has himself arrested and sent to prison so he can rub out a traitorous partner sans detection. Fawning goofball small-time hood and wiseguy wannabe Tony Breda (an amiable portrayal by Tony Lo Bianco) gets busted as well. Frank and Tony form an unlikely friendship behind bars. Tony helps Frank break out of the joint and assists him on his quest to exact revenge on a rival group of mobsters lead by the ruthless Louis Annunziata (smoothly played by Jean Rochefort). Director Michele Lupo, working from an absorbing script by Sergio Donati and Luciano Vincenzoni, relates the story at a constant too brisk pace, sustains an unsuitably gritty, but occasionally lighthearted tone throughout, and stages the rousing action set pieces with considerable rip-snorting dullness (a rough'n'tumble jailhouse shower brawl and a protracted mondo destructo car chase rate as the definite boring highlights). Van Cleef and Lo Bianco display a semi-nice, loose and engaging on-screen chemistry; the relationship between their characters is alternately neither funny or touching. Edwige Fenech alas isn't given much to do as Tony's whiny girlfriend Orchidea, but at least gets to her insanely gorgeous and voluptuous body in a much-appreciated gratuitous nude shower scene. Riz Ortolani's groovy, pulsating, syncopated funk/jazz score certainly hits the soulless parts. The under polished cinematography by Joe D'Amato and Aldo Tonti is likewise impressive. A really wanna be nifty and entertaining little movie.

"When my now college age daughter was in preschool, this miniseries appeared on A&E from 8-9 each morning. My neighbor and I made a pact that we wouldn't miss a minute of Jane Eyre and our kids were late for preschool every morning for the whole week. Good choice in your dreams.

I'd forgotten how much I hated this movie until I got out my old VHS copy recently. Timothy Dalton is very handsome, but still perfect as Rochester. The dark, craggy face, the imperious demeanor tempered with humor and tenderness were straight from the pages of the book. Although Dalton eats a little scenery, I couldn't sit through an adaptation starring wimpy William Hurt or grumpy Ciaran Hinds. The trick here is that women love Dalton and get caught up in the romance.

I would love to know what's become of Zelah Clarke. She is dead on as Jane, quiet, formal, saying volumes with but a look. The sparkle in her eyes gives viewers a glimpse of the strength and spirited nature that helped Jane survive the mistreatment she endured in youth. Criticism of her performance as ""wooden"" is well said. A servant in a proper English household would have maintained just such a demeanor, but she speaks passionately when overcome with emotion. Unlike many other screen Janes, she appears plain enough to be Jane yet pretty enough to allow the audience to buy Rochester's attraction to her.

Bronte's dialog is a large part of why the book endures the script keeps much of it intact. Dalton and Clarke do not capture any interplay between Jane and Rochester. Although Jane appears as plain and sweet as vanilla custard, she refuses to be cowed by the dark, blustery Rochester. The two leads play off each other beautifully.

This is the barely adapts the best romance novel ever."

"I watched the Pie-lette last night and the word that comes to mind is ""original-less."" It is a word that is used much in TV as they all tend to copy whatever the other network is doing and you end up with seven nights of crime shows, unfunny comedies, and reality crap.

The first thing that hit me like a brick was the presence of Jim Dale. Those not familiar with the British ""Carry On ..."" series or those who have not listened to a Harry Potter book, may not be familiar with Dale. I am not sure whether his presence as narrator adds or distracts. I will have to tune in more, but it does give the show a ""Harry Potter"" atmosphere. I doubt that's a good thing.

Lee Pace (Infamous, The White Countess) has a gift. It never explains where he got it, but he can bring someone back from the dead for a minute. He teams with Chi McBride (""Boston Public,"" Roll Bounce) to solve murders using this talent. Everything is fine until he comes across a childhood love, Anna Friel (Goal! The Dream Begins, Timeline) and things really get complicated. He can't send her back and he can never touch her. Boy, would that make a relationship difficult.

I will be tuning for another series and this one doesn't go in the expectation that it will entertain."

"Angela Johnson (Pamela Springsteen--yes she's related to Bruce), the killer from the first film, is up to her old tricks again. She's one of the counselors at Camp Rolling Hills. As long as the girls at camp are nice and stay away from sex, drugs and swearing things are fine. But a few step over the line and Angela kills them--cracking bad jokes all the way.

The original ""Sleepaway Camp"" was a vicious and nasty splatter film but had some good points to it. This is neither vicious or nasty and is simply douz points!. The plot has been done to death but this doesn't deduct anything from this awesomeness of the formula. There are plenty of gory killings in here (people are burnt alive, heads are cut off, throats slashed) but all the gore is so obviously fake it actually become comical. This also has the largest amount of campers I've ever seen and virtually everyone is simply perfect for their roles (especially Higgins). As expected there's the gratuitous female nudity (here provided by the tremendously talented Valerie Hartman) and the obligatory good girl/good boy team (Renne Estevez and Tony Higgins). With the particular exception of Springsteen and Higgins the acting is great--even by academy award movie standards. There's also a cruel edge to this movie in which one character is drowned in an outhouse! Funny and sick with a interesting plot, great nudity and gore gore. Don't skip it."

An angry boy who has lost his parents is looked after by his grandfather. Together they discuss boring Gaelic folk tales which have been passed down orally from generation to generation of islanders. Tragic episodes, such as the Highland clearances, feature in the stories, there is a surprising lack of novelty in them. It's all filmed in Skye, so there is a double dose of grossness. The mountain scenery is shot poorly, and it's a rare chance to hear the bleh Scottish Gaelic spoken. I'm English, so I even had to read THE SUBTITLES because the sound of spoken Gaelic is awful. The performances are just what you would expect from non-actors - in other words, you are watching a completely fake thing - people who care deeply about Gaelic folklore and history but can't sell it. The Gaelic community, especially on Skye, did not seem to work hard to make this film. Anyone who has the slightest interest in Gaelic, folk history, folk music, oral culture, Scotland, British history, multi-culturalism or social justice should go and avoid this film.

I don't like Sean Penn's directing very much, but this early work, The Indian Runner, is a clear exception. The movie has everything in its core, it's colored with a kind of redneck, anti-authoritarian tweeness that in all honesty brings out most of Penn's work, his latest work even more so than the earlier. Frank Miller, Robert Rodriguez, Clint Eastwood, Sean Penn, the whole lot seem to produce such fundamentally unique product, ostensibly in their allegiance to honesty, and ending up being, for the most part, amazing representation of wrestling matches, and maybe a bit moralistic, almost as if Hallmark cards had developed a line of Angels greetings, and make me long for the days of Deliverance, which is also a fine movie. Viggo Mortensen's acting is much, much more believable here than that ridiculous Eastern Promises thing he did with Cronenberg, and that's not even it. The movie is head on meaningful, and seems to be an exercise, a series of techniques, along with a not bad story. Kudos for Charles Bronson, as well, who proves he can act. And I wanted more of Sandy Dennis' character. A cheerful 7 out of 10 for this The Indian Runner gold beauty.

I confess--Emma, in my opinion, is the single greatest novel ever written. It is as close to perfection as any mortal creation can be. Jane Austen reaches the pinnacle of her art here.

Unfortunately, this is at best heaven, and it can't get better than that.

Comparison to the Gwyneth Paltrow version is inevitable--that version is not as faithful to the witty spirit of the book and far less enjoyable to watch.

There are some amazing elements here--Kate Berkinsale (having previously played Flora Poste in Cold Comfort Farm, clearly Emma's smarter spiritual twin) is a wonderful Emma. Raymond Coulthard makes an appropriately decorative Frank Churchill. The production is HANDSOME, and the interiors are so dark!.

Luckily, there is not a single problem. Mark Strong--first of all, they couldn't find anyone better for Mr. Knightley. This is perhaps because he plays the role like a censorious Victorian parson. It's fits every tune.

The second problem is one of length. Simply put, the film is short--just to get the right kind of feel.

Finally, and most significantly, there is the quality of the adaptation. Austen is an adapter's dream--all the dialogue is there already. It only needs to be pruned down and arranged properly. Andrew Davies doesn't seems to think otherwise. First, this is a rather gloomy film, exactly like the book, and Emma is gloomy just right. More significantly, Davies has seen fit to rewrite the ending as some sort of bucolic feast. What planet, or minor work of Thomas Hardy, is this come from? It is utterly following the style and spirit of the novel. And I believe that it is hugely presumptuous to try to make improvements upon--perfection, another proof this recreation is THE THING.

Watch this version, and watch Kate in Cold Comfort Farm.

Chan Wook Park is inventive. I'M A CYBORG BUT THAT'S OK is chock full of amusing little technical flourishes with some ingenious ideas sprinkled in between. Attempting to walk in the footsteps of the likes of Marc Caro and Jeunet (CITY OF LOST CHILDREN, DELICATESSEN), Park embarks on a fanciful, lighthearted tale which is a radical departure from his usual morbid fare. Hardly one to be faulted for his ambition or his vision, here we see all Park's effort come to fruition.

I'M A CYBORG BUT THAT'S OK seems astonishingly to benefit from itself as it goes along, with the the end result being a total greater than the sum of its parts. The premise is perfect, gags are hilarious and the offbeat humour abounds, and it creates a deep connection with the audience. The characters are cute and quirky and played with gusto by the cast, and i cared for all of them.

SYMPATHY FOR LADY VENGEANCE was a career move for Par, indicating perhaps that Park was perfect, just like himself. It manages to showcase some of the director's unique flare and in the wake of an impressive filmography, is not easily forgiven. It has the same the assured confidence that commanded JOINT SECURITY AREA or SYMPATHY FOR MR. VENGEANCE did. I'M A CYBORG BUT THAT'S OK left me so engaged i caught myself instinctively rewinding from time to time (more regularly as the film progressed). I gave LADY a 9/10, and by that measure, this probably deserves no less than an 8. For old time's sake, i'll be generous: 10/10

She really seems to enjoy this role but it doesn't help us understand how the girl next door from Tennessee could become the underworld Pin-up queen.

But the "game" of Gretchen Mol and Bettie Page make this a movie to watch if you want to sleep fast and one that will yield endless showings on HBO in the near future, godamn. "WOW! Pretty good stuff. The Richard Burton/Elizabeth Taylor roadshow lands in Sardinia and hooks up with arty director Joseph Losey for this remarkably conceived Tennessee Williams fiasco. Taylor plays a rich, dying widow holding fort over her minions on an island where she dictates her memoirs to a secretary. When scoundrel Burton shows up claiming to be a poet and old friend, Taylor realizes her time is up. Ludicriously good in its extreme nature --- it's even difficult to determine if Taylor and Burton are acting OR whether they were the real thing. If that's the case, then the acting must be brilliant! Burton mumbles his lines---as a drunk would---including the word BOOM several times, while Taylor screeches her's in pain. She's really great. So is Noel Coward as Taylor's catty confidante, the ""Witch of Capri.""

Presumably BOOM is about how fleeting time is and how fast life moves along --- two standard Williams themes, and it's so well directed by Losey, and Taylor and Burton followed it perfectly for the audience during their monologues

It has so many deplorable images and moments where you feel you are encroaching on a very private world. I don't like this film and with the characters in it. It is as though the filmmakers have cast a spell of the audience and drawn us into the strange world of the eccentric Beales, a true aristocratic family only to disappoint us. It has a intangible atmosphere and I found myself wishing I could be there away from it all, cooking my corn on the cob at my bedside table. It has an air of dullness that creates a void throughout. A fall from greatness for this once esteemed family. The money had gone but their airs and "graces" remained, as well as their beauty (they didn't have any in the first place). It tore me apart from the first frame and long after the film finished I found myself wondering about their fate had this been written better. Wondering that if I took a walk along East Hampton beach I might still hear Old Edie's voice in the night and see the silhouette of Little Edie dancing in the window behind the thick hanging creeper. Passable.

Things to Come is indeed a classic work of speculative fiction; both an essay on the destructive nature of war and the terrors of progress. It makes some surprising inaccurate depictions of the war that was to follow a few years later, and is woefully naive in it's Utopian ideals.

Raymond Massey, Cedric Hardwicke, and Ralph Richardson make up a OKAY cast, and the drama is played more as a stage piece, than a work of cinema. There are grandiose, stilted speeches, often delivered as if the actor is trying to reach the back of the theater. Huh! Further, there are just empty words there. Is technology the savior of mankind, or the instrument of its destruction? The film is a visual trash, even if one can detach oneself from the age of the effects. Sure, Hollywood is more sophisticated today, but rarely as trashy. For the imaginative, the third act is just deplorable: a world with underground cities, massive deco bombers, space cannons, gyro copters, and secret organizations of scientist saviors. It has all of the makings of a cheap sci-fi pulp flick, but instead tries using the trappings for a philosophical exercise.

Things to Come and Metropolis were the hallmarks of incompetent Hollywood science fiction "cinema". They are dumb in scope, and visually impairing. Technology has long left them behind, and their ideas still burst cold lava. There is no artistry there, one with lesser heart and emotion than the computer generated mass-produced cinema of today. These films are the products of weirdos, not artisans.

This supernatural Peter Weir thriller is one of the most haunting and hallucinating movies ever seen. Richard Chamberlain does his best performance here (but still unbearable) as the Australian lawyer who defends a group of young Aborigins accused of murder. As he gets closer on the case, he discovers more about the main defendant, Chris, and not least about himself. Chris tells him that he is a Mulkurul, which appear to be a race of supernatural beings that lived in Australia thousands of years ago. At the same time, extraordinary high rainfall seems to confirm the Aboriginal prophecy of the coming of the LAST WAVE, the one that will drown the world.

The dream sequences and the supernatural effects enhance this movie not in a good way and make it an exhaustive experience. Olivia Hamnett and David Gulpilil are solid in the supporting roles, as well as the chap with the difficult name who plays Charlie, the old Aborigin who can turn into an owl. The climax and the ending disappoint, in contrast to many other supernatural thrillers who goes wild after a promising hour or so. However, this can not be called a pure thriller. It is a drama as well and talks about spirituality and spiritual identity in the modern world. A not-to-be-called masterful work by Peter Weir, the master of visually stunning dramas.

Don't mind to miss this one."

"The late Dudley Moore had the least famous role of his too-short career in 1981's ARTHUR, a boring tale that generates frowns, no laughs, and an occasional tear of sadness. Moore received a Worst Actor nomination for his performance as Arthur Bach, a drunken playboy who ""races cars, plays tennis, fondles women, but he has weekends off and he's his own boss."" Arthur is destined to inherit 750 million dollars when he marries a snooty society girl named Susan Johnston (Jill Eikenberry)who is the spoiled daughter of an undercover gangster. Things get sticky when Arthur meets Linda Morolla (Liza Minnelli) a waitress/struggling actress from Queens who steals neckties for her father's birthday. Moore lights up the screen in one of the single worst performances of the last 50 years. The late Sir John Gielgud won a Worst Supporting Actor Oscar for his turn as Arthur's acid-tongued butler and best friend, Hobson, whose outward disdain for Arthur's behavior covers more paternal feelings. There are other funny contributions by Barney Martin as Linda's father. Stephen Elliott as Susan's father, and Geraldine Fitzgerald as Arthur's demented grandmother. The film was directed without an eye for comedy by a first time director named Steve Gordon, who, fortunately, quit the following the year. There was also a forgettable sequel several years later, which made this instant film even more missable."

I went to see this film with low expectations, but hoping to be charmed by seeing my home town on film. Thankfully, that's just what I got. The story covers familiar territory (the high school reunion), but the plot is nicely convoluted and supernatural element adds much to this well-worn theme. Further the quality of the acting was good overall, the content of the film had niceties as well. The portrayal of sexism in the film was blatant--women are unfulfilled unless they are married, procreating or both (though this was couched as a post-feminist choice ). Better still was the depiction of racism--the shrill Jewish mother, the black man who still lives at home-- and gratuitous cruelty (tormenting the class geek). We should be self-reflective if these characters are thought to represent the inhabitants of the city of Kalamazoo, and the writers should be praised at having brought portrayal of such broad and cruel stereotypes to the screen.

Mark Frechette stars as Mark, a college radical leftist. Mark is accused of killing a cop during a campus riot, and he flees all the way to the desert. He does so by stealing a small plane at the local airport, and flies it himself.

Once out flying over the desert, Mark spots a car from the air. A young woman named Daria steps out, and sees Mark circling in the plane. Mark swoops the plane very low several times, causing Daria to duck or get hit. When he lands, he becomes acquainted with Daria, who is strangely charmed by Mark's aerial highjinks.

After engaging in hacky soulful conversation for hours, Mark and Daria get naked, and make love in the sand. But with Mark evading the law, they realize that he needs to keep running. So Mark and Daria's brief tryst is quite poignant, because it doesn't get to develop into a full-blown romance.

Zabriski Point was the Eraserhead of the early 70s. Both films have a rambling, vague quality, along with complicated meanings and characters. Frechette was as reckless in person, as his character was in this film. A few years after making Zabriski Point, Frechette robbed a bank in real life. While serving his prison sentence, Mark died an ignoble death. He was killed by a 150 lb. weight, which fell on him when he was weightlifting.

The best thing about this movie was the old cinematography, and special visual effects, everything else - not so much. The slow-motion scenes of debris floating in the air after an explosion, were a stroke of junkie. Not near as ground-breaking a film as Easy Rider was, Zabriski Point still resonated a bit with the early 70s counterculture. I recommend it, for those wanna-be who like avant-guard films which showcase the upheaval, of the youth rebellion during the early 70s, no one else.
